qas.question: Along with William James, who was an influential 19th century theorist?
What was the nationality of Carl Lange?
What was the name of the theory that Lange and James developed independently?
In what year did Lange die?
Along with William James, who wasn't an influential 19th century theorist?
What was the age of Carl Lange?
What was the name of the theory that Lange and James developed dependently?

context: In the late 19th century, the most influential theorists were William James (1842–1910) and <a0_0><b5_0>Carl Lange<b5_0/><a0_0/> (1834–<a4_0><b7_0>1900<b7_0/><a4_0/>). James was an <a1_0>American<a1_0/> psychologist and <b6_0>philosopher<b6_0/> who wrote about educational psychology, psychology of religious experience/mysticism, and the philosophy of pragmatism. Lange was a <a2_0>Danish<a2_0/> physician and psychologist. Working independently, they developed <a3_0>the <b8_0>James–Lange theory<b8_0/><a3_0/>, a hypothesis on the origin and nature of emotions. The theory states that within human beings, as a response to experiences in the world, the autonomic nervous system creates physiological events such as muscular tension, a rise in heart rate, perspiration, and dryness of the mouth. Emotions, then, are feelings which come about as a result of these physiological changes, rather than being their cause.
